thought_leadership.label: Thought Leadership Post
thought_leadership.content:
Hot take: Most AI coding tools optimize for the wrong metric.

They measure keystrokes saved. Lines generated. Time to first commit.

But here's what actually matters -- did the developer make the right architectural decision? Did they catch the edge case that would've become a 3am production fire in 6 months?

At FlowState, we don't build autocomplete. We build the engineering judgment that takes 10 years to develop.

(Yes, I'm biased. But I've also been the person debugging someone else's AI-generated spaghetti at 2am. So.)

personal_story.label: Personal Story Post
personal_story.content:
Six months ago I turned down a $12M Series A.

Everyone thought I was insane. My advisor literally said 'You're going to regret this.'

The terms were generous. The firm was top-tier. The only catch: a board seat and approval rights over key hires.

I thought about it for exactly one climbing session. (That's where I make my best decisions -- 60 feet up, nowhere to hide from the truth.)

The answer was no.

Three weeks later we closed an $8M SAFE. Less money. Full control.

I haven't regretted it once. Speed is the only thing that matters when you're pre-PMF. Capital is a tool. Control is oxygen.

(And yes, my mom was concerned about the smaller number. But she sent a heart emoji when I explained. We're good.)

connection_request.label: Connection Request
connection_request.content: Hi -- saw your post on developer experience metrics. We're solving a similar problem at FlowState (measuring decision quality instead of output velocity). Would love to compare notes if you're up for it.

thought_leadership.editedContent:
Hot take: Most AI coding tools optimize for the wrong metric.

They measure keystrokes saved. Lines generated. Time to first commit.

Nobody measures: did the developer avoid the rabbit hole? Did they catch the thing that becomes a 3am page in 6 months?

We're building FlowState for the second question.

(Yes, I'm biased. But I've also been the one debugging AI-generated spaghetti at 2am. So.)
thought_leadership.whatDidntWork: Too long. The middle section was over-explaining. I'd never write 'engineering judgment that takes 10 years to develop' -- too formal, sounds like a pitch deck.
thought_leadership.whatWouldHelp: Keep it punchier. I write in short bursts, not paragraphs. And I say 'rabbit hole' not 'architectural decision' in casual posts.

personal_story.whatDidntWork: Pretty close. The climbing metaphor felt natural. Only thing -- I wouldn't write 'Capital is a tool. Control is oxygen.' That's too polished, too quotable. Real me would just say 'Money is replaceable. Speed isn't.'
personal_story.whatWouldHelp: Avoid aphorisms that sound like they belong on a motivational poster. My actual wisdom comes out messier.
